comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: It looks like a lovely warm summer's day - tennis on the lawn, a young lady with obligatory hat lazing in the long grass, and air-conditioning on at the hospital (i.e. windows open)

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Freeman's of May 17th 1898 reports at great length on the Lucina Fete and Fancy Fair in aid of the Rotunda Hospital (Lucina being the goddess of childbirth, as I've just learned). ... On the tennis courts the band of the Dublin Metropolitan Police rendered a charming musical program, which was listened to by the crowds that promenaded with manifest pleasure. On the rising ground at the northern side of the gardens there was a variety of invigorating amusements in full swing including merry-go-rounds, switchbacks, galloping horses, shooting galleries, variety entertainments &c. There was also a tug-of -war contest and a splendid display by the Dublin Gymnasium team, including an exhibition of boxing "in which the science of the manly sport was excellently shown". Not much use as dating evidence, except I think we can tentatively rule out the possibility that it was taken on the 16th or 17th May 1898. That only leaves about 3650 possible days in the 1890s.

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: Ah, but! The inscription on the print would perhaps suggest that this is in fact a photograph produced for postcard printing? In which case we should be able to narrow the dates down a bit.... If it wasn't Francis Frith then maybe one of the other major postcard producers of the day?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
As [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66148392@N07] says, the 25" maps have survey dates from 1888 to 1913, which hardly narrows it down from just knowing it's a Lawrence picture.

Do you know if the W.L index numbers follow any system? (this one being 2257).

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Ok, deep breath, because this is not at all scientific. From all of our work here on Flickr, here's some examples of good-ish dates that we've more or less established: Born to Run, L_CAB_495: Circa 1902 19 minutes past 11 o'clock, L_CAB_814: Circa 1900 Written out of history, L_CAB_2631: 1890-1912-ish? Tunnel Cottage, Glengariff, L_CAB_8742: Circa 1906
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
Hmmm, it is still possible that these index numbers are chronological, then, and I think Born to Run is a firm 1902, so that would make this into the 1900s rather than 1890...

Not enough to go on yet, but worth keeping in mind.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Hmmm, indeed! And Tunnel Cottage, Glengariff is a solid 1906/07. As I say, not completely scientific, but an indicator...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content: OSI give the dates for the 25" as 1897 - 1913, but that's not to say the courts weren't there before. I've looked high and low about the tennis courts, but can't find much by way of date. There was a bowling green there before the tennis courts, and by all accounts, the gardens used to be quite a party place. The Rutland School for Ladies, run by Ms. McCutcheon on 28 Rutland Square, used the tennis court (Irish Times, Advert, 1897), so perhaps that is one of her girls we can see on the court!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: While researching the origins of the Donnybrook Rugby ground I found in the Bective Rangers website that Bective College was situated on Rutland (Parnell) Square just across from the Rotunda.  They played their rugby on a small field just out of view of this shot in the site of the modern Garden of Remembrance.  This area was a hotbed of activity in its time.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Using my new patent map dating algorithm (see comments here), the 25" map linked above was surveyed on 1st Jun 1907.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Loving your new patent map dating algorithm!!

So the map was surveyed on 1 June 1907.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/66105333@N06] bronbee above reports: 'In 1905 a new building was begun to give additional accommodation for patients and nursing staff.... and grass lawn-tennis courts laid down in the Master's gardens' .
Can we go for 1907, based on the above, and on the clothes that we can see on the reclining lady??
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I think around 1907 is better than 1890s, but it could still be as late as 1913, right?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] We'll go for 1907 for the moment anyway...
